official-title.#text:
Expressing the necessity for the Members of
		  the House of Representatives to use the term

term.#tail:
when referring to foreign nationals which are
		  working in the United States without proper documentation.

sponsor.#tail:
submitted
			 the following resolution; which was referred to the

term.#tail:
because no human being is
			 illegal;

text.#text:
Members of the House of Representatives no
			 longer use the term

human beings need to be central in
			 immigration discussions in order to move toward a more civilized and humane
			 tone in public discourse and policies on immigration; and

foreign nationals,
			 undocumented immigrant, unauthorized immigrant, immigrant without papers and
			 immigrant seeking status are examples of terms we can use that do not
			 dehumanize people. We can all stop unintentionally fueling racial profiling and
			 violence directed toward immigrants, when we drop the word

term.#text:
undocumented
			 immigrant, non citizen, or people here in violation of the immigration
			 laws

text.#text: Whereas the use of the term is included in

act-name.#text:
Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant
			 Responsibility Act of 1996

term.#tail:
may cause
			 negative sentiments toward the targeted population, it is our responsibility to
			 encourage a national dialogue that is respectful of humanity and frame a debate
			 that is productive and free of terms that label a person's status as illegal or
			 creates a negative connotation and ill will towards that person;

text.#text:
Whereas all parties have expressed a desire for
			 comprehensive immigration reform;

Whereas the use of the term has caused delay in the
			 negotiations of immigration reform; and

Whereas it would give us the opportunity to move forward
			 in the process of revising United States immigration laws with a universal
			 term: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 155 IH: Expressing the necessity for the Members of the House of Representatives to use the term undocumented instead of the term illegal when referring to foreign nationals which are working in the United States without proper documentation.
